msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Numbers 11
ab.l:
And the people were seeking bad pretexts in the hearing
of the Lord, and the Lord heard it and his anger was kindled, and
the fire of the Lord burned among them and consumed at the edge
of the camp.

And the people cried to Moses,
and Moses prayed to the Lord, and the fire died down.

And he called the name of the place Taberah, because
the fire of the Lord burned among them.

And the rabble
that was among them craved a craving: and
the children of Israel, as well, returned and said, ‘Who shall feed
us meat?’

We remembered the fish that
we ate in Egypt for free, the cucumbers, and the
water-melons, and the cabbages, and the onions, and the garlic.

But now our soul is dried away. There is nothing,
our eyes look with longing only at manna.’

And the manna was like coriander seed
in size, and its appearance in whiteness like that of the bottom of a pearl.

And the people spread
and gathered it and ground it in mills or
beat it in a mortar and cooked it in a pot or
made cakes |of it|: and the taste of it was
as the oiliness of oil.

And
when the dew descended on the camp at night, the
manna descended on it.

And Moses heard
the weeping people by their families, each man in the door
of his tent, and the anger of the Lord was kindled greatly, and
it seemed bad in Moses’s eyes.

And Moses said
to the Lord, ‘Why have you done bad to your servant, and why have I not found
favour in your sight, that you wanted to lay the burden of all this
people on me?

Did I conceive
all this people? Or have I
given birth to them, that you should say to me, “Carry them as if |they were|
in your bosom to the land which you swore to give to their fathers, like
the one who brings up a sucking child?”

From where shall meat come to me to give it to all this people,
that they weep before me, saying, “Give us meat,
that we may eat.”

I am not able to carry
the burden of all this people alone, because it is too heavy for me.

And if you deal thus with me, kill me
now, if I have found favour in your eyes,
and let me not see my wretchedness.’

And the Lord said
to Moses, ‘Gather to me seventy men of the elders
of Israel whom you know to be the elders of the people and
their overseers, and bring them to the tent of meeting, that they may stand
there with you.

And my divine Presence will come down
and I will talk with you there. And I will separate some of the inspiration
which is on you and I will put it on them, and they shall bear
the burden of all the people with you, so that you may not bear it
yourself alone.

And say to the people, “Prepare
yourselves for the daybreak, and you will eat meat, for you have wept in the ears
of the Lord, saying, “Who shall feed us meat, because
we had it better in Egypt,” and the Lord will give you meat,
and you will eat.

Until a month of days!
Until it comes out of your nose and it becomes poison to you.
Because you have despised the Lord’s word who is among you,
and you have wept before him, saying, “Why is this that we went out
from Egypt?””’

And Moses said,
‘The people, among whom I am, are six times a hundred thousand footmen, and you
have said, “I will give them meat, that they may eat a month of days.”

I am asking you for this, so that you may explain to me: will the flocks and
cattle be slain for them to suffice them? Will the fish
of the sea be gathered together for them to suffice them?’

And the Lord said to Moses, ‘Does the Lord’s strength
get tired? Now you will see whether my word happens to you or
not.’

And Moses went out and spoke to the people
the words of the Lord, and gathered seventy men
of the elders of the people, and stood them
all around the tent.

And the Lord’s divine Presence came down
in a cloud and spoke to him, and he separated
some of the inspiration that was on him and gave it to the seventy men,
the elders. And it was when the spirit camped on them:
and they prophesied. And they did not continue |doing it|.

But there remained two of the men in the camp, the name of the
one was Eldad, and the name of the second was Medad. And
the inspiration rested on them. And they were of them that were written,
but they did not go out to the tent, and they prophesied in the camp.

And a boy ran and told Moses, and
said, ‘Eldad and Medad do prophesy in the camp.’

And Joshua, son of Nun, the servant of Moses
from his chosen ones, answered and said, ‘My lord Moses, put them in prison.’

And Moses said to him, ‘Are you jealous
for me? And who would make it |so| that all of the Lord’s people
were prophets, that the Lord would put his
inspiration on them!’

And Moses was gathered back
to the camp, he and the elders of Israel.

And
a wind travelled from before the Lord and tore out quails
from the sea and cast them by the camp, about a day’s journey
in this direction, and about a day’s journey in this direction, all around
the camp, and about two cubits high above the face
of the earth.

And the people stood up all that day
and all that night and all the next day, and they gathered
the quail. The one who had the least gathered
ten piles. And they spread them out for themselves, spreading around
the camp.

And the flesh was still
between their teeth, before it vanished, and the anger of the Lord
was kindled against the people, and the Lord struck the people with a very great plague.

And he called the name of that place Kibroth-
-Hattaavah, because they buried the people that craved for meat there.

And the people journeyed from Kibroth-Hattaavah
to Hazeroth, and they were in Hazeroth.

app.note: K: I; a scribal error, cf. Heb. נִשְׁבַּעְתָּ ‘you swore’.
